prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded.
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. The victim is wearing a pair of metal glass. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot. The balloon is empty. 
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago.
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion.
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The corpse that went crashin' through the Crystal Tower had a broken neck.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 1
Testimony: I, I made a minor miscalculation in the angle of the beam projection, that's all! That was my mistake!
Person: Harebrayne
Testimony 2
Testimony: But the post-mortem examination revealed another injury. A fatal wound.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 3
Testimony: There was a lesion in his chest where he'd clearly been stabbed by somethin' sharp right in the heart!
Person: Gregson
Testimony 4
Testimony: So the victim was killed before he went anywhere. And this fella's the only one who could have done it!
Person: Gregson
Testimony 5
Testimony: The weapon the victim was stabbed with must have been left in his body whilst he was beamed through the air!
Person: Gregson

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, let's try to figure this out. So, I'm given a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies from a murder case. My task is to find a pair where evidence contradicts testimony. The user wants only one pair, so I need to carefully analyze each piece to spot the conflict.

First, I'll go through the testimonies one by one and see which ones might be contradicted by the evidence.

Starting with Testimony 0: "The corpse that went crashin' through the Crystal Tower had a broken neck." This suggests that the victim's neck was broken, which would imply that the death was due to a fall or some external force causing a broken neck. 

Looking at the evidence, Evidence 6 is the Autopsy Report, which states that the victim's neck was broken from a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object. So, the testimony aligns with the autopsy report. That doesn't contradict anything yet.

Testimony 1: "I, I made a minor miscalculation in the angle of the beam projection, that's all! That was my mistake!" This seems to be the defendant, Professor Harebrayne, admitting to a mistake in the machine's angle, which caused the victim to crash into the Crystal Tower. 

Now, looking at Evidence 3: The Screwdriver. It says the screwdriver was found poking through the grille in the base of the kinesis machine and has traces of blood matching the victim's wound. This suggests that the screwdriver was used to stab the victim. 

But according to Testimony 1, Harebrayne claims the victim was killed by a mistake in the beam projection, not by a stabbing. So here's a contradiction: the evidence (screwdriver with blood) suggests a stabbing, while the testimony claims the death was due to the beam miscalculation.

Wait, but the Autopsy Report (Evidence 6) also mentions a stab wound. So, there's more than one way to kill here. But the testimony is specifically about the cause of death being the beam, not the stabbing. So, the testimony is trying to downplay the stabbing, but the evidence shows the stabbing happened.

Therefore, the pair that contradicts each other is Evidence 3 (Screwdriver with blood) and Testimony 1 (Harebrayne's claim of miscalculation causing death without stabbing).

I think that's the contradiction. The evidence supports the stabbing, while the testimony tries to dismiss it, suggesting the primary cause was the beam miscalculation.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me start by going through the details provided.

First, I see that there are several characters involved, including suspects, victims, and various witnesses. The main characters seem to be Professor Albert Harebrayne, his financial backer Odie Asman, and the victim, who perished in an explosion at the Great Exhibition. The explosion involved a machine that Harebrayne invented, which caused a lot of damage, including the Crystal Tower.

Looking at the evidences, there's a lot of technical details. Evidence 3 is about a crossbow found under a tree, and it's mentioned that it belongs to Mr. Enoch Drebber. Evidence 5 is a photograph of the victim showing a stab wound to the chest. There's also an autopsy report (Evidence 6) stating that the victim was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object and had a broken neck from a violent fall.

The testimonies include statements from Professor Harebrayne. Testimony 1 says, "My hypothesis states the kinesis cannot transport metal, though. Hence the metal weapon would have stayed put." Testimony 2 says, "In other words, the point just raised by Mr Naruhodo isn't an inconsistency at all." Testimony 3 says, "Mr Asman was the patron of my research. Without him, my work wouldn't have been possible." Testimony 4 says, "Now I have a duty to protect the incredible machine that we built together!"

Now, I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's look at the testimonies first. 

In Testimony 1, Harebrayne mentions that his hypothesis states the kinesis cannot transport metal, meaning the metal weapon would have stayed put. This suggests that the metal screwdriver, which was found in the victim's chest, would have remained there because kinesis can't move metal. But in Evidence 7, the screwdriver is described as having traces of blood at the tip and matching the shape of the victim's wound. This seems contradictory because if kinesis can't move metal, the screwdriver should still be at the scene, but the victim was found with it in his chest, implying it was transported there.

Looking at Testimony 2, Harebrayne says that the point raised by Mr. Naruhodo isn't an inconsistency. This could be referring to the previous testimony, where he discussed the inability of kinesis to transport metal. However, if the screwdriver was found in the victim's chest, that would contradict the hypothesis that metal can't be transported, suggesting that the kinesis did move the metal screwdriver, which would mean his hypothesis is incorrect.

Therefore, the contradiction seems to be between Evidence 7 (the screwdriver found in the victim's chest) and Testimony 1 and 2, where Harebrayne claims that kinesis can't transport metal. This inconsistency arises because the presence of the metal screwdriver in the victim's chest suggests that the kinesis did transport it, which contradicts his hypothesis.

So, the evidence (Evidence 7) and the testimonies (Testimony 1 and 2) contradict each other.
</think>

cot:
Alright, let's try to figure this out. I'm presented with a complex scenario involving multiple characters, evidences, and testimonies. My task is to identify which piece of evidence contradicts a particular testimony, and then present that as a JSON response.

First, I'll need to carefully read through all the characters, evidences, and testimonies to understand the context and relationships between them. There's a lot here, so I'll start by summarizing the key points.

The main characters involved include Susato Mikotoba, Iris Wilson, Herlock Sholmes, Mael Stronghart, Odie Asman, Albert Harebrayne, Barok van Zieks, the Masked Man, Gina Lestrade, Tobias Gregson, Esmeralda Tusspells, Balthazar Lune, the Bohemian Boy (Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein), Courtney Sithe, and Enoch Drebber.

Looking at the evidences, there's a lot of details about the Great Exhibition, the kinesis machine, and the aftermath of the explosion. Key pieces include the Armband, the Great Exhibition Newspaper, the Experiment Sketch, the Mysterious Contraption (which is a crossbow belonging to Enoch Drebber), the Piece of Green Cloth, the Photograph of the Victim, the Autopsy Report, the Screwdriver, the Photograph of the Balloon, Drebber's Card, the Wooden 'Birdcage', the Photograph of Drebber, the Camera, the Piece of Broken Glass, the Science Trophy, the Waxwork Head, the Killer's Autopsy Report, the Post-Explosion Photograph, Drebber's Contract, and the Ten-Year-Old Article.

The testimonies involve various characters recounting events surrounding the explosion and the subsequent investigation. For example, Balthazar Lune mentions his balloons being undamaged, Gina Lestrade describes the sequence of events, Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein (the Bohemian Boy) provides his perspective, and others add their accounts.

Now, I need to find a contradiction between one evidence and one testimony. To do this, I'll look for a testimony that directly contradicts an evidence point.

Looking at Evidence 5: "A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. The victim is wearing a pair of metal glass. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest." This suggests that the victim was wearing metal glasses and had a stab wound.

Now, looking at Testimony 2: "And from amid ze smoke...a cage appeared out of nowhere!" This testimony suggests that after the explosion, a cage suddenly appeared from the sky and crashed into the Crystal Tower.

But wait, if the cage fell from the sky, and the victim was inside the cage, then the victim would have been wearing the same clothes when he was 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. However, the evidence states that the victim was wearing a pair of metal glasses, which might not align with the cage's appearance from the sky.

Alternatively, considering the context, if the cage fell from the sky, it's possible that the victim was inside the cage, which would mean he was wearing the same outfit as when he was 'beamed'. But the evidence says he was wearing metal glasses, which might not make sense if he was in a cage that fell from the sky. Or perhaps the metal glasses were part of his attire when he was 'beamed', and the cage's appearance doesn't affect that.

Wait, perhaps the key point is that if the cage fell from the sky, the victim would have been inside it, and thus would have been wearing the same clothes as when he was 'beamed'. But the evidence says he was wearing metal glasses, which might not align with the cage's appearance. Alternatively, maybe the metal glasses were part of the 'beaming' process.

I think I need to focus on the specific details. If the cage fell from the sky, the victim would have been inside it, and thus would have been wearing the same clothes as when he was 'beamed'. But the evidence states that the victim was wearing metal glasses, which might not align with the cage's appearance. Alternatively, perhaps the metal glasses were part of the 'beaming' process, and the cage's appearance doesn't affect that.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction lies in the fact that if the cage fell from the sky, the victim would have been inside it, and thus wouldn't have been wearing metal glasses, but the evidence says he was. Or maybe the metal glasses were part of the 'beaming' process, and the cage's appearance doesn't affect that.

Alternatively, maybe the cage's appearance from the sky would have caused the victim to be disrobed or something, but the evidence says he was wearing metal glasses.

I'm not entirely sure, but I think the key is that the cage falling from the sky would mean the victim was inside it, and thus would have been wearing the same clothes as when he was 'beamed'. But the evidence says he was wearing metal glasses, which might not align with the cage's appearance.

So, I think Evidence 5 contradicts Testimony 2. Evidence 5 says the victim was wearing metal glasses, while Testimony 2 suggests the cage fell from the sky, implying the victim was inside it. If the cage fell from the sky, the victim would have been wearing the same clothes as when he was 'beamed', which might not include metal glasses, or perhaps the metal glasses were part of the 'beaming' process, making the testimony inconsistent with the evidence.

After considering, I believe the contradiction is between Evidence 5 and Testimony 2.
</think>

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded.
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. The victim is wearing a pair of metal glass. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot. The balloon is empty. 
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago.
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion.
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: As I said, Balthazar Lune is no liar! Every balloon I had in the sky landed safely!
Person: Lune
Testimony 1
Testimony: All three of my balloons were carrying passengers. If they fell to the ground in an esplosione, what a catastrofe!
Person: Lune
Testimony 2
Testimony: But ya can't get away from the fact that a burnt-up bit o' cloth was found at the scene, can ya?
Person: Gina
Testimony 3
Testimony: The coppers at the Yard reckoned it was prob'ly some debris thrown from the explosion on the stage.
Person: Gina
Testimony 4
Testimony: This stupido ragazzo is mistaken! My balloons have the red and blue zigzag stripes anyway!
Person: Lune

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony are contradicting each other. I have a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies. I need to find one pair where evidence and testimony directly contradict each other.

First, I'll go through the testimonies to see what each one is saying.

Testimony 0: Balthazar Lune says he's not a liar and that all his balloons landed safely.
Testimony 1: He mentions that if his balloons fell to the ground in an explosion, it would be a catastrophe.
Testimony 2: Gina points out that a burnt piece of cloth was found at the scene, suggesting some debris from the explosion.
Testimony 3: She says the police think it was debris from the stage explosion.
Testimony 4: Lune claims that his balloons have unique stripes, so they couldn't be the ones that caused the debris.

Now, looking at the evidence, I see that Evidence 5 is a photograph of the victim showing a stab wound to the chest. Evidence 4 is the green cloth piece found under the stage, with scorch marks.

Testimony 2 and 3 both mention the burnt cloth and link it to the stage explosion. But Testimony 4 contradicts this by saying Lune's balloons have unique stripes, so they couldn't be the ones causing the debris. This seems like a contradiction because if Lune's balloons didn't cause the debris, then the burnt cloth must have come from somewhere else, possibly the stage explosion.

So, the evidence (Evidence 4 and the burnt cloth) supports the idea that the debris came from the stage, while Testimony 4 from Lune contradicts that by claiming his balloons are unique and thus not responsible. This means Evidence 4 and Testimony 4 are contradicting each other.
</think>
